name: cherry
content:
cherry

noun
 
/ˈtʃeri/
 
/ˈtʃeri/
(plural cherries)
Idioms
jump to other results
  1. enlarge image
    [countable]     a small soft round fruit with shiny red or black skin and a large seed inside see also black cherry (2)Topics Foodb2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • black
    • red
    • glacé
    • …
    … of cherries
    • bunch
    cherry + noun
    • pit
    • stone
    • pie
    • …
    See full entry
  2. (also cherry tree)
     [countable] a tree on which cherries grow, or a similar tree, grown for its flowers
    • cherry blossom
    • a winter-flowering cherry
    see also black cherry (1)Topics Plants and treesb2
  3. (also cherrywood
     
    /ˈtʃeriwʊd/
     
    /ˈtʃeriwʊd/
    )
     [uncountable] the wood of the cherry tree see also black cherry (3)
  4. (also cherry red)
     [uncountable] a bright red colour
    More Like This Colour compoundsColour compounds
    • baby blue
    • china-blue
    • cobalt blue
    • electric blue
    • ice-blue
    • midnight blue
    • navy blue
    • peacock blue
    • petrol blue
    • powder blue
    • royal blue
    • sky-blue
    • blood-red
    • cherry red
    • pillar-box red
    • wine red
    • bottle-green
    • emerald green
    • jade green
    • lime green
    • olive-green
    • pea-green
    • sea-green
    • lemon yellow
    • primrose yellow
    • lily-white
    • snow-white
    • coal-black
    • jet black
    • pitch-black
    • charcoal grey
    • iron-grey
    • slate-grey
    • rose pink
    • salmon pink
    • shocking pink
    • nut-brown
    5. Word OriginMiddle English: from Old Northern French cherise, from medieval Latin ceresia, based on Greek kerasos ‘cherry tree, cherry’. The final -s was lost because cherise was interpreted as plural (compare with pea).
Idioms
a bite at/of the cherry
  1. (British English) an opportunity to do something
    • You only get one bite at the cherry in life.
    • They were eager for a second bite of the cherry.
See cherry in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: cherry

name: cherry bomb
content:
cherry bomb

noun
 
/ˈtʃeri bɒm/
 
/ˈtʃeri bɑːm/
(North American English)
jump to other results
  1. a small, round, red firecracker that explodes with a very loud noise
    • Two fans were injured after a cherry bomb was thrown at them.
    • (figurative) In her new movie, Weaver is a cherry bomb about to explode.
See cherry bomb in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: cherry bomb

name: black cherry
content:
black cherry

noun
 
/ˌblæk ˈtʃeri/
 
/ˌblæk ˈtʃeri/
jump to other results
  1. (also black cherry tree)
     [countable] a type of North American cherry tree
    • Wild black cherry trees are native to Central Kentucky.
    Topics Plants and treesc1
  2. [countable] the sour (= not sweet) black fruit of the black cherry tree
    • black cherry jam/yogurt
    Topics Foodc1
  3. [uncountable] the valuable hard wood of the black cherry tree
    • This salad bowl is made of black cherry.
See black cherry in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: black cherry

jump to other results

name: cherry picker
content:
cherry picker

noun
 
/ˈtʃeri pɪkə(r)/
 
/ˈtʃeri pɪkər/
jump to other results
  1. a type of tall crane that lifts people up so that they can work in very high places
  2. a person who cherry-picks
    • He's a cherry picker who only fights smaller guys.
See cherry picker in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary

name: cherry-picking
content:
cherry-picking

noun
 
/ˈtʃeri pɪkɪŋ/
 
/ˈtʃeri pɪkɪŋ/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the act of choosing the best people or things from a group and leaving those that are not so good
    • There can be no cherry-picking of statistics that happen to support your case.

name: maraschino
content:
maraschino

noun
 
/ˌmærəˈʃiːnəʊ/,
 
/ˌmærəˈskiːnəʊ/
 
/ˌmærəˈʃiːnəʊ/,
 
/ˌmærəˈskiːnəʊ/

jump to other results
  1. [uncountable, countable] a strong, sweet alcoholic drink made from black cherries

     [countable] a cherry preserved in maraschino used to decorate alcoholic drinks

name: bite
content:
bite

noun
 
 
/baɪt/
 
/baɪt/
Idioms
jump to other results

    using teeth

  1.  
     [countable] an act of biting
    • The dog gave me a playful bite.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + bite
    • have
    • swallow
    • take
    • …
    preposition
    • between bites
    • bite from
    • bite of
    • …
    See full entry
  2. [countable, usually singular] the way the upper and lower teeth fit together
    • He has to wear a brace to correct his bite.
    3.

    food

  3.  
     [countable] a small piece of food that you can bite from a larger piece
    • She took a couple of bites of the sandwich.
    • He didn't eat a bite of his dinner (= he ate nothing).
    Extra Examples
    • She tried to talk between bites.
    • She took a huge bite out of the chocolate bar.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + bite
    • have
    • swallow
    • take
    • …
    preposition
    • between bites
    • bite from
    • bite of
    • …
    See full entry
  4. a bite (to eat) [singular] (informal) a small amount of food; a small meal
    • How about a bite of lunch?
    • We just have time for a bite to eat before the movie.
    • We managed to grab a bite at the airport.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • quick
    verb + bite
    • grab
    • have
    preposition
    • bite of
    phrases
    • a bite to eat
    See full entry
    5.

    of insect/animal

  5.  
     [countable] a wound made by an animal or insect
    • Dog bites can get infected.
    • a mosquito/snake/insect bite
    • a bite from a poisonous snake
    • There was a bite mark on his arm.
    Topics Health problemsb1
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryadjective
    • dog
    • insect
    • mosquito
    • …
    verb + bite
    • get
    bite + noun
    • mark
    preposition
    • bite from
    See full entry
    6.

    strong taste

  6. [uncountable] a pleasant strong taste
    • Cheese will add extra bite to any pasta dish.
    7.

    cold

  7. [singular] a sharp cold feeling
    • There's a bite in the air tonight.
    8.

    powerful effect

  8. [uncountable] a quality that makes something effective or powerful
    • The performance had no bite to it.
    • The sun had lost some of its bite by then.
    9.

    of fish

  9. [countable] the act of a fish biting food on a hook
    • The fishermen waited all afternoon for a bite.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + bite
    • have
    • swallow
    • take
    • …
    preposition
    • between bites
    • bite from
    • bite of
    • …
    See full entry
    10. see also frostbite, love bite, sound bite
    Word OriginOld English bītan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch bijten and German beissen.
Idioms
somebody’s bark is worse than their bite
  1. (informal) used to say that somebody is not really as angry or as aggressive as they sound
a bite at/of the cherry
  1. (British English) an opportunity to do something
    • You only get one bite at the cherry in life.
    • They were eager for a second bite of the cherry.
See bite in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: bite
matches: bite the hand that feeds you
bite off more than you can chew
somebody’s bark is worse than their bite
relatives: bite the hand that feeds you
